column2: handsome

column1: austen#It was Miss Taylor ' s loss which first brought grief . It was on the wedding - day of this beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought of any continuance . The wedding over

column8: suitable age

A large debt of gratitude was owing here ; but the intercourse of the last seven years

column1: austen#In this state of her spirits

column4: on very easy terms

column10: after giving the particulars of the house and garden

column14: herself

column16: for the houses were in the same parish
column17: could

He seemed really anxious to accommodate them and the whole of his letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of giving pleasure to his cousin ; more especially at a moment when she was suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of her nearer connections .

column1: austen#She needed no time for deliberation or inquiry . Her resolution was formed as she read . The situation of Barton

column6: was now its first recommendation . To quit the neighbourhood of Norland was no longer an evil ; it was an object of desire ; it was a blessing
column7: in comparison of the misery of continuing her daughter - in - law ' s guest ; and to remove for ever from that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or visit it while such a woman was its mistress . She instantly wrote Sir John Middleton her acknowledgment of his kindness
column8: and her acceptance of his proposal ; and then hastened to shew both letters to her daughters
column9: that she might be secure of their approbation before her answer were sent . Elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for them to settle at some distance from Norland
column10: than immediately amongst their present acquaintance .

column1: austen#On THAT head
column2: therefore
column3: it was not for her to oppose her mother ' s intention of removing into Devonshire . The house
column4: too
column5: as described by Sir John
column6: was on so simple a scale
column7: and the rent so uncommonly moderate
column8: as to leave her no right of objection on either point ; and
column9: therefore
column10: though it was not a plan which brought any charm to her fancy
column11: though it was a removal from the vicinity of Norland beyond her wishes
column12: she made no attempt to dissuade her mother from sending a letter of acquiescence . CHAPTER 5 No sooner was her answer dispatched
column13: than Mrs . Dashwood indulged herself in the pleasure of announcing to her son - in - law and his wife that she was provided with a house
column14: and should incommode them no longer than till every thing were ready for her inhabiting it . They heard her with surprise . Mrs . John Dashwood said nothing ; but her husband civilly hoped that she would not be settled far from Norland .

column1: austen#"She had great satisfaction in replying that she was going into Devonshire .-- Edward turned hastily towards her
column2: on hearing this
column3: and
column4: in a voice of surprise and concern
column5: which required no explanation to her
column6: repeated
column7: "" Devonshire ! Are you
column8: indeed
column9: going there ? So far from hence ! And to what part of it ?"" She explained the situation . It was within four miles northward of Exeter ."

column1: austen#""" It is but a cottage
column2: she continued
column3: "" but I hope to see many of my friends in it . A room or two can easily be added ; and if my friends find no difficulty in travelling so far to see me
column4: I am sure I will find none in accommodating them ."" She concluded with a very kind invitation to Mr . and Mrs . John Dashwood to visit her at Barton ; and to Edward she gave one with still greater affection . Though her late conversation with her daughter - in - law had made her resolve on remaining at Norland no longer than was unavoidable
column5: it had not produced the smallest effect on her in that point to which it principally tended . To separate Edward and Elinor was as far from being her object as ever ; and she wished to show Mrs . John Dashwood
column6: by this pointed invitation to her brother

column1: austen#He really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion ; for the very exertion to which he had limited the performance of his promise to his father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable .-- The furniture was all sent around by water . It chiefly consisted of household linen
column2: plate
column3: china
column4: and books
column5: with a handsome pianoforte of Marianne ' s . Mrs . John Dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh : she could not help feeling it hard that as Mrs . Dashwood ' s income would be so trifling in comparison with their own
column6: she should have any handsome article of furniture . Mrs . Dashwood took the house for a twelvemonth ; it was ready furnished
column7: and she might have immediate possession . No difficulty arose on either side in the agreement ; and she waited only for the disposal of her effects at Norland
column8: and to determine her future household
column9: before she set off for the west ; and this
column10: as she was exceedingly rapid in the performance of everything that interested her

column12: and an opportunity now offering of disposing of her carriage

column1: austen#HER wisdom too limited the number of their servants to three ; two maids and a man
column2: with whom they were speedily provided from amongst those who had formed their establishment at Norland . The man and one of the maids were sent off immediately into Devonshire
column3: to prepare the house for their mistress ' s arrival ; for as Lady Middleton was entirely unknown to Mrs . Dashwood
column4: she preferred going directly to the cottage to being a visitor at Barton Park ; and she relied so undoubtingly on Sir John ' s description of the house
column5: as to feel no curiosity to examine it herself till she entered it as her own . Her eagerness to be gone from Norland was preserved from diminution by the evident satisfaction of her daughter - in - law in the prospect of her removal ; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed under a cold invitation to her to defer her departure . Now was the time when her son - in - law ' s promise to his father might with particular propriety be fulfilled . Since he had neglected to do it on first coming to the estate
column6: their quitting his house might be looked on as the most suitable period for its accomplishment . But Mrs . Dashwood began shortly to give over every hope of the kind
column7: and to be convinced

column9: that his assistance extended no farther than their maintenance for six months at Norland .

column1: austen#"He so frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping
column2: and of the perpetual demands upon his purse
column3: which a man of any consequence in the world was beyond calculation exposed to
column4: that he seemed rather to stand in need of more money himself than to have any design of giving money away . In a very few weeks from the day which brought Sir John Middleton ' s first letter to Norland
column5: every thing was so far settled in their future abode as to enable Mrs . Dashwood and her daughters to begin their journey . Many were the tears shed by them in their last adieus to a place so much beloved . "" Dear
column6: dear Norland !"" said Marianne
column7: as she wandered alone before the house
column8: on the last evening of their being there ; "" when shall I cease to regret you !-- when learn to feel a home elsewhere !-- Oh ! happy house
column9: could you know what I suffer in now viewing you from this spot
column10: from whence perhaps I may view you no more !-- And you
column11: ye well - known trees !-- but you will continue the same .-- No leaf will decay because we are removed
column12: nor any branch become motionless although we can observe you no longer !-- No ; you will continue the same ; unconscious of the pleasure or the regret you occasion
column13: and insensible of any change in those who walk under your shade !-- But who will remain to enjoy you ?"""

column1: austen#CHAPTER 6 The first part of their journey was performed in too melancholy a disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant . But as they drew towards the end of it
column2: their interest in the appearance of a country which they were to inhabit overcame their dejection
column3: and a view of Barton Valley as they entered it gave them cheerfulness . It was a pleasant fertile spot
column4: well wooded
column5: and rich in pasture . After winding along it for more than a mile
column6: they reached their own house . A small green court was the whole of its demesne in front ; and a neat wicket gate admitted them into it .

column1: austen#As a house
column2: Barton Cottage
column3: though small
column4: was comfortable and compact ; but as a cottage it was defective
column5: for the building was regular
column6: the roof was tiled
column7: the window shutters were not painted green
column8: nor were the walls covered with honeysuckles . A narrow passage led directly through the house into the garden behind . On each side of the entrance was a sitting room
column9: about sixteen feet square ; and beyond them were the offices and the stairs . Four bed - rooms and two garrets formed the rest of the house . It had not been built many years and was in good repair . In comparison of Norland
column10: it was poor and small indeed !-- but the tears which recollection called forth as they entered the house were soon dried away .

column1: austen#They were cheered by the joy of the servants on their arrival

column5: and at no great distance on each side ; some of which were open downs
column6: the others cultivated and woody . The village of Barton was chiefly on one of these hills

column8: and reached into the country beyond .

column2: and in another course

column5: to be sure
column6: said she
column7: "" it is too small for our family

column4: of course

column11: cold

column1: austen#The house was large and handsome ; and the Middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality and elegance . The former was for Sir John ' s gratification

column4: they strongly resembled each other in that total want of talent and taste which confined their employments
column5: unconnected with such as society produced
column6: within a very narrow compass . Sir John was a sportsman
column7: Lady Middleton a mother . He hunted and shot
column8: and she humoured her children ; and these were their only resources .

column1: austen#Lady Middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil her children all the year round
column2: while Sir John ' s independent employments were in existence only half the time . Continual engagements at home and abroad
column3: however

column5: and gave exercise to the good breeding of his wife . Lady Middleton piqued herself upon the elegance of her table
column6: and of all her domestic arrangements ; and from this kind of vanity was her greatest enjoyment in any of their parties . But Sir John ' s satisfaction in society was much more real ; he delighted in collecting about him more young people than his house would hold
column7: and the noisier they were the better was he pleased . He was a blessing to all the juvenile part of the neighbourhood

column2: pretty
column3: and unaffected . It was enough to secure his good opinion ; for to be unaffected was all that a pretty girl could want to make her mind as captivating as her person . The friendliness of his disposition made him happy in accommodating those

column10: who welcomed them to Barton Park with unaffected sincerity ; and as he attended them to the drawing room repeated to the young ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from him the day before
column11: at being unable to get any smart young men to meet them . They would see

column4: and as she was a very cheerful agreeable woman
column5: he hoped the young ladies would not find it so very dull as they might imagine . The young ladies
column6: as well as their mother
column7: were perfectly satisfied with having two entire strangers of the party
column8: and wished for no more . Mrs . Jennings
column9: Lady Middleton ' s mother
column10: was a good - humoured
column11: merry
column12: fat
column13: elderly woman
column14: who talked a great deal
column15: seemed very happy
column16: and rather vulgar . She was full of jokes and laughter

column18: and pretended to see them blush whether they did or not .

column1: austen#Marianne was vexed at it for her sister ' s sake
column2: and turned her eyes towards Elinor to see how she bore these attacks
column3: with an earnestness which gave Elinor far more pain than could arise from such common - place raillery as Mrs . Jennings ' s . Colonel Brandon
column4: the friend of Sir John
column5: seemed no more adapted by resemblance of manner to be his friend
column6: than Lady Middleton was to be his wife
column7: or Mrs . Jennings to be Lady Middleton ' s mother . He was silent and grave . His appearance however was not unpleasing
column8: in spite of his being in the opinion of Marianne and Margaret an absolute old bachelor
column9: for he was on the wrong side of five and thirty ; but though his face was not handsome
column10: his countenance was sensible
column11: and his address was particularly gentlemanlike . There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend them as companions to the Dashwoods ; but the cold insipidity of Lady Middleton was so particularly repulsive
column12: that in comparison of it the gravity of Colonel Brandon
column13: and even the boisterous mirth of Sir John and his mother - in - law was interesting . Lady Middleton seemed to be roused to enjoyment only by the entrance of her four noisy children after dinner
column14: who pulled her about
column15: tore her clothes
column16: and put an end to every kind of discourse except what related to themselves .

column1: austen#In the evening
column2: as Marianne was discovered to be musical
column3: she was invited to play . The instrument was unlocked
column4: every body prepared to be charmed
column5: and Marianne
column6: who sang very well
column7: at their request went through the chief of the songs which Lady Middleton had brought into the family on her marriage
column8: and which perhaps had lain ever since in the same position on the pianoforte
column9: for her ladyship had celebrated that event by giving up music
column10: although by her mother ' s account
column11: she had played extremely well
column12: and by her own was very fond of it . Marianne ' s performance was highly applauded . Sir John was loud in his admiration at the end of every song
column13: and as loud in his conversation with the others while every song lasted . Lady Middleton frequently called him to order
column14: wondered how any one ' s attention could be diverted from music for a moment
column15: and asked Marianne to sing a particular song which Marianne had just finished . Colonel Brandon alone
column16: of all the party
column17: heard her without being in raptures .

column1: austen#He paid her only the compliment of attention ; and she felt a respect for him on the occasion
column2: which the others had reasonably forfeited by their shameless want of taste . His pleasure in music
column3: though it amounted not to that ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with her own
column4: was estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of the others ; and she was reasonable enough to allow that a man of five and thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every exquisite power of enjoyment . She was perfectly disposed to make every allowance for the colonel ' s advanced state of life which humanity required . CHAPTER 8 Mrs . Jennings was a widow with an ample jointure . She had only two daughters
column5: both of whom she had lived to see respectably married
column6: and she had now therefore nothing to do but to marry all the rest of the world .

column1: austen#In the promotion of this object she was zealously active
column2: as far as her ability reached ; and missed no opportunity of projecting weddings among all the young people of her acquaintance . She was remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments
column3: and had enjoyed the advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of many a young lady by insinuations of her power over such a young man ; and this kind of discernment enabled her soon after her arrival at Barton decisively to pronounce that Colonel Brandon was very much in love with Marianne Dashwood . She rather suspected it to be so
column4: on the very first evening of their being together
column5: from his listening so attentively while she sang to them ; and when the visit was returned by the Middletons ' dining at the cottage
column6: the fact was ascertained by his listening to her again . It must be so . She was perfectly convinced of it . It would be an excellent match
column7: for HE was rich
column8: and SHE was handsome .

column1: austen#"Mrs . Jennings had been anxious to see Colonel Brandon well married
column2: ever since her connection with Sir John first brought him to her knowledge ; and she was always anxious to get a good husband for every pretty girl . The immediate advantage to herself was by no means inconsiderable
column3: for it supplied her with endless jokes against them both . At the park she laughed at the colonel
column4: and in the cottage at Marianne . To the former her raillery was probably
column5: as far as it regarded only himself
column6: perfectly indifferent ; but to the latter it was at first incomprehensible ; and when its object was understood
column7: she hardly knew whether most to laugh at its absurdity
column8: or censure its impertinence
column9: for she considered it as an unfeeling reflection on the colonel ' s advanced years
column10: and on his forlorn condition as an old bachelor . Mrs . Dashwood
column11: who could not think a man five years younger than herself
column12: so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter
column13: ventured to clear Mrs . Jennings from the probability of wishing to throw ridicule on his age . "" But at least
column14: Mamma
column15: you cannot deny the absurdity of the accusation
column16: though you may not think it intentionally ill - natured ."

column1: austen#"Colonel Brandon is certainly younger than Mrs . Jennings
column2: but he is old enough to be MY father ; and if he were ever animated enough to be in love
column3: must have long outlived every sensation of the kind . It is too ridiculous ! When is a man to be safe from such wit
column4: if age and infirmity will not protect him ?"" "" Infirmity !"" said Elinor
column5: "" do you call Colonel Brandon infirm ? I can easily suppose that his age may appear much greater to you than to my mother ; but you can hardly deceive yourself as to his having the use of his limbs !"""

column1: austen#""" Did not you hear him complain of the rheumatism ? and is not that the commonest infirmity of declining life ?"" "" My dearest child
column2: said her mother
column3: laughing
column4: "" at this rate you must be in continual terror of MY decay ; and it must seem to you a miracle that my life has been extended to the advanced age of forty ."" "" Mamma
column5: you are not doing me justice . I know very well that Colonel Brandon is not old enough to make his friends yet apprehensive of losing him in the course of nature . He may live twenty years longer ."

column1: austen#"But thirty - five has nothing to do with matrimony ."" "" Perhaps
column2: said Elinor
column3: "" thirty - five and seventeen had better not have any thing to do with matrimony together . But if there should by any chance happen to be a woman who is single at seven and twenty
column4: I should not think Colonel Brandon ' s being thirty - five any objection to his marrying HER ."" "" A woman of seven and twenty
column5: said Marianne
column6: after pausing a moment
column7: "" can never hope to feel or inspire affection again
column8: and if her home be uncomfortable
column9: or her fortune small
column10: I can suppose that she might bring herself to submit to the offices of a nurse
column11: for the sake of the provision and security of a wife . In his marrying such a woman therefore there would be nothing unsuitable . It would be a compact of convenience
column12: and the world would be satisfied ."

column2: but that would be nothing . To me it would seem only a commercial exchange
column3: in which each wished to be benefited at the expense of the other ."" "" It would be impossible
column4: I know

column6: "" to convince you that a woman of seven and twenty could feel for a man of thirty - five anything near enough to love

column8: merely because he chanced to complain yesterday ( a very cold damp day ) of a slight rheumatic feel in one of his shoulders ."" "" But he talked of flannel waistcoats
column9: said Marianne ; "" and with me a flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches
column10: cramps
column11: rheumatisms
column12: and every species of ailment that can afflict the old and the feeble ."" "" Had he been only in a violent fever
column13: you would not have despised him half so much ."

column1: austen#"Confess
column2: Marianne
column3: is not there something interesting to you in the flushed cheek
column4: hollow eye
column5: and quick pulse of a fever ?"" Soon after this
column6: upon Elinor ' s leaving the room
column7: "" Mamma
column8: said Marianne
column9: "" I have an alarm on the subject of illness which I cannot conceal from you . I am sure Edward Ferrars is not well . We have now been here almost a fortnight
column10: and yet he does not come . Nothing but real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay . What else can detain him at Norland ?"""

column2: if I have felt any anxiety at all on the subject
column3: it has been in recollecting that he sometimes showed a want of pleasure and readiness in accepting my invitation
column4: when I talked of his coming to Barton . Does Elinor expect him already ?"" "" I have never mentioned it to her

column1: chesterton#GABRIEL SYME was not merely a detective who pretended to be a poet ; he was really a poet who had become a detective . Nor was his hatred of anarchy hypocritical . He was one of those who are driven early in life into too conservative an attitude by the bewildering folly of most revolutionists . He had not attained it by any tame tradition . His respectability was spontaneous and sudden
column2: a rebellion against rebellion . He came of a family of cranks
column3: in which all the oldest people had all the newest notions .

column1: chesterton#One of his uncles always walked about without a hat
column2: and another had made an unsuccessful attempt to walk about with a hat and nothing else . His father cultivated art and self - realisation ; his mother went in for simplicity and hygiene . Hence the child
